title: Angela Byars-Winston
text:
Angela Michelle Byars-Winston is a Professor of Internal Medicine at the <a href="University%20of%20Wisconsin%E2%80%93Madison">University of Wisconsin–Madison</a>. She was the first African American to achieve the rank of tenured Full Professor of medicine at the <a href="University%20of%20Wisconsin%E2%80%93Madison">University of Wisconsin–Madison</a>. She studies the impact of culture on career development, in particular for women and minorities in STEM. She is a Fellow of the <a href="American%20Psychological%20Association">American Psychological Association</a> and was one of <a href="Barack%20Obama">Barack Obama</a>'s Champions of Change.
Early life and education.
Byars-Winston earned her bachelor's (1991) and master's (1992) degree at <a href="San%20Diego%20State%20University">San Diego State University</a>. She completed a <a href="Predoctoral%20fellow">predoctoral</a> clinical fellowship at the <a href="University%20of%20Maryland%2C%20College%20Park">University of Maryland, College Park</a>. She attended <a href="graduate%20school">graduate school</a> at <a href="Arizona%20State%20University">Arizona State University</a>, specialising in <a href="counseling%20psychology">counseling psychology</a>. Her 1996 dissertation placed her on the national policy-making stage. She was one of only two black PhD students in the School of Education at Arizona State University in the fall of 1992.
Career.
Byars-Winston joined the <a href="University%20of%20Wisconsin%E2%80%93Madison">University of Wisconsin–Madison</a> as a KL2 scholar in 1997. She joined the School of Medicine in 2011 and became interested in whether people bring their identity to the foreground of their college experience. She was awarded a $1.4 million <a href="NIH%20grant">R01</a> <a href="National%20Institutes%20of%20Health">National Institutes of Health</a> grant to investigate how mentors define diversity and developing ways to measure the impact of mentored research experiences on career outcomes. She is part of a $19 million National Research Mentoring Network (NRMN). She has investigated how to measure mentoring interventions. She has conducted a longitudinal study that monitored how the relationships between undergraduate mentees and their mentors in the biological sciences impact their academic outcomes.
One of the approaches to meet the <a href="skills%20gap">skills gap</a> in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> is to engage "A"frican Americans, "L"atino/as, South East "A"sians, and "N"ative "A"mericans ('ALANA') with science and engineering subjects. Byars-Winston used <a href="Social%20cognitive%20theory">social cognitive</a> career theory to examine how ethnicity influenced academic self-efficacy and outcomes. She has identified several barriers to the progression of ALANA investigators, including the marginalisation of interests, apartheid within academia and <a href="microaggression">microaggression</a>s. Byars-Winston demonstrated that race and ethnicity impact career expectations more than aspirations. She launched the "Training and Education to Advance Minority Scholars in Science" program (TEAM-Science) and Culturally Aware Mentoring (CAM) programs, which look to embed self-reflective dialogue about race and ethnicity in science. She is working with the <a href="National%20Academy%20of%20Sciences">National Academy</a> to examine the effectiveness of programs that look engage individuals marginalised in STEM fields.
<a href="Barack%20Obama">Barack Obama</a> named Byars-Winston as one of the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>' Champions of Change in 2011. The <a href="Presidency%20of%20Barack%20Obama">Presidency of Barack Obama</a> established a "Educate to Innovate" campaign, which looked to improve the engagement of young people with science, technology, engineering and maths (STEM). She is a member of the <a href="https%3A//www.napequity.org/">National Alliance for Partnerships in Equity</a> STEM Equity Pipeline National Advisory Board and Wisconsin Career Development Association Executive Committee.
She won the <a href="University%20of%20Wisconsin%E2%80%93Madison">University of Wisconsin–Madison</a> "Outstanding Woman of Color Award" in 2014. In 2016 Byars-Winston was a Visiting Professor at <a href="Purdue%20University">Purdue University</a>, where she ran a series of mentoring workshops. She published the "Promising Practices for Strengthening the Regional STEM Workforce Development Ecosystem". In 2017 Byars-Winston became the first African American to achieve the rank of tenured Full Professor of medicine at the <a href="University%20of%20Wisconsin%E2%80%93Madison">University of Wisconsin–Madison</a>. She was elected to the <a href="National%20Academy%20of%20Sciences">National Academy of Sciences</a> Board of Higher Education and Workforce (BHEW).
